title: Trying That Lavender Tallow Balm on My Face: A Weird Winter Win
body:
Look, my skin was just mad at me. It was January, the heat was blasting, and my face felt like that cheap paper towel that disintegrates when it gets wet. Tight. Flaky around my nose. Just generally pissed off. I was using this fancy cream I got on sale for like, $42, and it did nothing. Less than nothing. It just sat there. I was scrolling on my phone one night, probably watching a baking video I’d never attempt, and this ad pops up for whipped tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. I almost scrolled past. I mean, come on.

But my knuckles were cracked and bleeding from washing my hands a thousand times a day. I was desperate. And the word “lavender” was there. Calming. Sleep stuff. My brain was a beehive at night. So I clicked. It was some small shop on Etsy, based in France. The pictures were simple. No crazy promises. Just grass-fed beef tallow, whipped, with lavender. I figured, what’s the worst that could happen? I’ve wasted more money on dumber things. I ordered the small jar. It was maybe twenty bucks with shipping. Forgot about it.

Then it showed up. This little glass jar in a lot of packing paper. And my natural skincare routine was about to get very, very natural.

## How Beef Tallow Ended Up in My Bathroom

Opening the jar was an experience. It didn’t smell like a candle store or a perfume counter. It smelled like… lavender, but the plant itself. Like if you crushed the flowers in your hand. Not sweet. Earthy. Herbal. Kind of strong, honestly. I poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It was solid but soft, like cold butter, but when you scoop some out it immediately starts to melt from your finger heat. I stood there in my bathroom, holding a glob of rendered cow fat, thinking “this is a new low” or maybe a new high, who knows.

I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand first. Rubbed it in. It vanished. Like, really soaked in. No greasy film. My skin just… drank it. That was the first surprise. My $42 cream never did that. It always left a sheen. This tallow balm just disappeared. So I got brave. Washed my face with my normal drugstore cleanser (the Cetaphil one, in the big pump), patted it dry, and took a pea-sized amount. Smeared it between my palms and just pressed it onto my face. Didn’t rub hard, just pressed.

It felt… rich. But not heavy. My skin felt quiet. That’s the only word. The tight, angry feeling was gone in maybe two minutes. I didn’t look magically different. I just felt normal. My face didn’t feel like it was wearing a mask. I went to bed. The lavender smell was strong on my pillow. Not in a bad way. It was just there. I usually toss and turn for an hour. That night? I was out. Could’ve been placebo. Could’ve been the fact I wasn’t stressing about my sandpaper face. Don’t care.

## What Switching to This Stuff Actually Did

So I kept using it. Just at night. My morning routine was still my vitamin C serum and a light moisturizer. But night time became tallow time. I’d say after a week, the daily use thing started showing. The flakiness around my nose and between my eyebrows? Gone. Completely. My foundation, when I bothered to wear it, stopped clinging to dry patches. It just looked like skin.

The real test was my hands. Remember the bleeding knuckles? I started slathering this tallow balm on them before bed, putting on cheap cotton gloves I found in a first aid kit. After three nights, the cracks started to heal. After a week, they were just… normal hands. Not baby soft, not “silky” whatever. Just functional, non-painful hands. That’s when I was like, okay, this isn’t a fluke. This beef tallow skincare thing, this mimicking human sebum stuff they talk about… it might be real.

I started using a tiny bit on my elbows and knees. Those are always rough, you know? Like alligator skin. They’re smoother now. Not perfect. But better. I ran out of my fancy eye cream (another $55 down the drain) and just used the tallow. No milia, no clogged pores. My under-eyes just look hydrated. No crazy transformation. No “ten years younger.” Just my skin, but like, when it’s having a good day and isn’t thirsty.

I got my mom one. She’s in her 60s and has really dry skin. She called me skeptical. “Tallow? Like beef fat?” I told her to just try it. She uses it on her cuticles now. Swears by it. I’m on my second jar. I keep it on my nightstand. The cat sometimes tries to sniff it and then looks deeply offended.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m probably gonna order another one soon because I’m using it for everything. A little on a dry patch on my ankle. A dab on my lips before bed. It’s just the one thing that actually absorbs and does the job. It’s not glamorous. The jar is simple. The concept is weird. But it works in this quiet, fundamental way that all my complicated, expensive products never did.

It’s not magic. It won’t give you glass skin or whatever. It just makes your skin not freak out. Especially in winter. It feels like you’re giving your skin what it actually wants, not some lab-created cocktail. The lavender scent is strong, which I like for nighttime. It signals my brain to shut off. If you hate lavender, they probably have an unscented one. I got mine from this little Etsy shop called “MT Lifestyle” or something like that. Shipping from France took a bit, but it was worth the wait.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult, feeling tight, looking flaky, and you’re tired of bottles that don’t deliver? Might be worth a shot. A weird, beefy, herbal shot. My skin’s happy. I’m sleeping better. That’s a win in my book.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yeah. The science-y reason is that it’s really similar to the oils our own skin makes. So it absorbs deep instead of sitting on top. It doesn’t just moisturize the surface, it seems to help your skin help itself. My face stopped feeling like it needed moisture every five minutes.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was terrified of this. I have combo skin that can get clogged. But this stuff? It sinks right in. It’s non-comedogenic, which means it shouldn’t clog pores. For me, it didn’t. If anything, my skin feels more balanced. Less oily in my T-zone because it’s not dehydrated and over-producing oil.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Not like a air freshener. It’s a real, herbal lavender smell. Like the essential oil, or the plant in a garden. It’s strong when you open the jar, but once it’s on your skin it mellows out pretty fast. It’s a relaxing, bedtime kind of smell. If you want something scent-free, they probably have that too.

So yeah. That’s my tallow story. My skin is just… better. I don’t know what else to say.
random_tangent: I should probably order another jar soon
